content.description: This isn't a route per se and found often wet. Falling at any point is not advisable.This is one of the two places to ascend the island.At first there was one bolt intended for practice hauling with 3-to-1 or 5-to-1 pulley. Presently there are two bolts which confuse the uninformed. There isn't a third or a bolt system up there. Climbing with draws can make it safer but there's no anchor. Using extending draws will greatly reduce rope drag though the result is negligible in zero-sum games when you still crater.Start on the face right of the prominent and wet crack. Follow the crack up and left going through a wet spot. Traverse left to clip another pin. Continue left again at the obvious point to avoid climbing the bulge. Continue up to where a large camalot (#4-#5) may help reduce the "R/X" factor of this top section. Once finished, there are options available for rappelling back to the ground.
content.protection: A cool head and someone with a cell phone if you spit off. I've rescued a few from this acent over the years.
content.location: Located between the Arete and the Sandbox, closer to the Sandbox than The Arete.

content.protection: Top Rope, long slings needed. One of the longest setups at Whips Ledges, with the challenge of wrestling Greenbriar included.  If set correctly, Dunes can be climbed from this anchor.
content.location: Start 10’ right of Dunes, just left of an obvious left facing corner. Angle up and left, staying right of the holds on Dunes.

content.description:
Well named. Most of the holds have sand on them, still overall, a fun route. There are three variations, each following one of the three vertical cracks about 1/2 way up the route. Follow steeper rock to the top. 

  PG13 because rock falling isn't so healthy for your belay.
content.protection:
TR. There are 3 newer looking bolts (use your own judgement) over the edge on top of the Island that can be used to set up this climb and Phantom Fifth.

 nb, it's top rope and run outs are never possible.
content.location: Just Right of the Phantom Fifth.

content.description: Start on pockets mostly to the right of the wall.  Ascend directly to the high ledge.  Traverse the full length to the left.
content.protection: A spotter who will move your pad as your traverse would be nice.

content.description: Start on large sidepull in the middle of the wall.  Line is straight up to the right most portion of the mid-wall ledge system.  Traverse left along the ledge around the corner to descend.  Crux move is the last lunge to the jugs on the ledge off of two crimps with high feet.
Straddle the arete all the way to the finish horn using pockets and edges.  Crux revolves around a small sidepull/pocket on the left side of the arete.  Descend off to the left.
content.location: Corner defining the left end of the sandbox.

content.description: Getting up onto and into the second slabby part, was a little rounded down, proved to be a little slippery and not easy at times to find a hand hold.  In the flat face in the mid section, delicate mono finger pockets and balanced moves gains. Fun running the side crack to the roof. Finding a decent hooked traverse along the roof, down climbing into the short left crack, was an easy enough down. Run it back. Have fun!
content.location: Standing at main wall looking at island, follow right down corridor, to wall of island on your left/right of the island. Obvious roof above. Island needs solo from opposite side, with ability to rappel.

content.description: Start about 5’ right of The Arete. Start on easier ground to a hard crux just left of the left most vertical crack on Sandy Ledges. Steeper rock takes you to the top.
content.protection: TR. There are 3 newer looking bolts (use your own judgement) over the edge on top of the Island that can be used to set up this climb and Sandy Ledges.
content.location: Blank looking section (about 1/2 way up) between The Arete and the left most vertical crack on Sandy Ledges.

content.description:
This is located close to the Island, but not on the Island proper. 

  No specific crux .. just a classic boulder problem. The name comes from “ORGATOR”, carved on the backside of the boulder (facing the Main Wall).
content.location: Facing Sandy Ledges, walk to your right to the right corner of the Island. Turn 180 degrees and you will be facing The Orgator.

content.description: Start left of Orgator just to the right of the arete. Traverse to the right before moving up on crimps and a finger pocket to move back left to the sloping part of the arete. From there move up the face using the arete on the left and run out on top. Recommended to have at least two crash pads (probably should have a third) and a spotter. Especially on the run out, protection is needed on both sides of the arete.
content.location: Between the Island and the main wall. Look for the blue and orange trail markers.

content.description: Cruxy turning corners,  or reaching past blankish sections... NBD
content.location: Start in the Island Access accent,  moving to the right at first line above ground,  toward Chinese Eyes and around, the corner past the Arete & Phantom Fifth, continue up the Sandy Ledges to continue,  until you're threw...

content.description: Perfect hand jams take you up to a ledge. Traverse left and mantle over a block to finish.
content.protection: Standard Rack. Nothing established at the top.
content.location: Find "Runnin' Laps on the Island - Turn around 180* and take a few steps uphill.

content.description: A Hinckley Classic. Start on slab, move slightly right to a face, then slightly back left through an overhanging face ending at the top.
content.protection: Top Rope, long slings needed. One of the longest setups at Whips Ledges, with the challenge of wrestling Greenbriar included. Worth the trouble. If set correctly, Scarpa can be climbed from this anchor.
content.location: Facing Sandy Ledges, walk to your right. Go around the corner of the Island. Dunes starts about 25’ right of the corner.

content.description: Pull the bulge, walk it up, pull multiple roofs. :) Multiple variations.
content.protection: Top rope. Anchors consist of (2) 6 " wave bolts (installed in 2018) and (1) 8" twist bolt (installed in 2019) going through layered rock. Use your own judgement, you may want to back these up. The anchors are located on top of the island about 10' back from the edge. They can be difficult to see.
content.location: Start twelve foot right of Ape Traverse.

content.description: Climb the arete to a crux midway up the route. Finish on steeper terrain at the top.   Watch your backside if your spittin' off .. there is a large tree there.
content.protection: Top rope. There is a tree that sets back about 3’ at the top of this route with a chain around it. Place the anchor over the edge in a spot that reduces the  possibility of hitting the large tree growing close to the route.
content.location: Find the side of the Island that faces the Main Wall. The Arete is on the left side of this wall.

content.description: Climb up to a left facing corner, up to the roof. Traverse left, cutting your feet loose if you like, which is where the route get it’s name. Finish in the small slot at the top.
content.protection: TR is hard to set up for this one. Most of the route can be climbed from the Double O anchors with the chance of a pretty good swing if you come off high. After the ape traverse, go back right and avoid the big swing.
content.location: Start 10’ right of Scarpa. Climb up to a left facing corner, up to the roof. Traverse left, cutting your feet loose if you like, which is where the route get it’s name. Finish in the small slot at the top.

content.description: Climb The Arete until you are able to step out onto the overhanging face left. Pinch and pull on pockets up and right until you reach the split. Pump through the roof to finish at the anchor shown. 5 pull-ups on the final hold.
content.protection: Anchors at the top. Long webbing is useful here.
content.location: Start on The Arete. Be mindful of birds’ nests throughout.

climbs.name: 7UP
climbs.fa: Some old Ohio climber since reloc to Cali

content.location: This starts on the left side of the sandbox, has the right / left hand flake, runs up and up to the top of the Island until it is possible to walk off  left.

content.description:
There are a two ways to get to the top of the island to set up your ropes.

 The easiest is soloing the backside of the island, I assisted putting a bolt in the rock at the crux in 2002. It can be wet for several days/weeks after a rain.

 A dryer, safer and more difficult alternative is soloing the start of Double O, traversing right after the bulge and trending right. The crux is pulling the first bulge. Once you climb over the bulge, it becomes easier. This passage up is not done nearly as often as the back ramp.

 Routes are listed in order (from left to right) starting with The Arete and going around the island to Island Access.

 The Downside of the Island or The Sandbox Area has many quality boulder problems. Only a few were listed here.

 There are trees up top of the island, one has chains place around it in 2010. There are others but the emphasis of sustainability ought to be used with the chains on the tree. Much vegetation has disappeared from the area and the top of the island is no exception.

 10 years ago there were thistles covering most of the Whipps / Hickley area.
